text:
HOST: So I'm joined by
three very prestigious, very accomplished people.

So Mike Lyons is a
serial entrepreneur, an adjunct lecturer at Stanford,
and a venture capitalist

across five different funds. He's founded numerous companies. He is currently the chairman
of two high tech startups,

a general partner with
NativeFirst Capital, and managing director of
NewLine Ventures, an incubator.

He was the founding professor
of the class MS&E 273 or CEE 246, which was Tech
Venture Formation now called

Venture Creation for
the Real Economy. And we're going to talk a
little bit more about that class because it's been
here at Stanford,

I think Mike and Ray,
for three decades now. So it's really an
institution here. And I want to talk
a little bit more

about that, how they've run
it and how it's running now. In addition to that, he's
built other programs with CGOE

here at Stanford, in
particular a program that we ran for many years
called The Idea to Market.

He's joined by Dr.
Ray Levitt, who served on the faculty of MIT
Civil Engineering Department

until 1980 and then
came here to Stanford and joined the Civil and
Environmental Engineering faculty at Stanford till
about 2017 when he retired.

He founded and was
the academic director of the Stanford Advanced
Project Management program, which was an incredibly
successful program, also run

through CGOE. We were at CPD. That ran for about 20 years, and
I think issued more than 9,000

certificates. During his time at
Stanford, he also co-founded three
software startups.

So in addition to being an
instructor and a teacher and running the
education side, he has also founded three
software startups.

He is the president of the
Farmers Investment Club, an angel investment group of
Stanford faculty and affiliates.

And upon retiring
from Stanford in 2017, he became an operating
partner of Blackhorn Ventures

and has led the firm's
early stage investments in more than 20 startups
focused on the construction and real estate sectors.

So very varied career,
really interesting. I know, Ray, we've had
a chance to talk before. I always love hearing more
about the interesting journey

you've had. We're also joined by
James Currier, who is a five-time founder and angel
investor in DoorDash, Lyft,

and Patreon, and a
founding partner at NFX. Before becoming
an angel investor, James was the co-founder
and CEO of Tickle,

one of the internet's first
successful user-generated companies. James has co-founded three
other successful companies--

Wonderhill, IronPearl, and Jiff. And as a lifelong learner
and developer of talent,

James loves sharing
wisdom among founders. And I really encourage you
to check out the NFX site.

I think it's nfx.com. James, correct me if I'm
wrong, but it's really a wonderful set
of resources, also

have wonderful
webinars, articles, things that are just really,
really valuable resource there.

Well, thank you, all three
of you, for joining us. And thank you everyone in the
audience for joining us today. Again, today, we want
to just go through

is what it takes to launch
a successful venture. And the way, as we
were talking earlier, I see the structure is just
starting with your experiences

as founders, as people
running these companies, and then moving on
to your roles as VCs

and what you've seen
as you've engaged with lots of different companies
and coaching them through it.

And then kind of ending
to talk about how you can teach and learn
those skills outside of maybe that coaching
environment of being

a VC and a little opportunity to
talk about the specific classes that we have here at Stanford.

So James, would you
mind kicking us off? Just could you give
us a little bit more about your background
and maybe a focus on your time as a founder,
as someone working?

And what were the
hard lessons you learned as a
student, so to speak, of launching a
successful venture?

JAMES CURRIER: Yeah, you bet. So I went to Princeton and
I started a couple companies

while I was at Princeton. Actually, I took a year off. So the entrepreneurial
bug was part of me

from the very beginning. I got out and ended up
working at Battery Ventures as an associate back when
there was only 40 venture

firms in the US. And it was about
150 general partners working in venture and
about 75 associates.

I was one of the associates. And so I got an early look at
the industry in '94 to '97.

And when I got out of Harvard
Business School in '99, I started Tickle.

And while I was at
school, I was taking all the courses I could
to really understand what I was in for.

I was reading books on the side. I was going off campus to
different tech conferences.

We didn't really have startup
conferences back then, but we had tech conferences
that I would go down to.

And then when I got out, I
started my first-- actually, I started my first company
during the last year
of my business school. And I got the name wrong. I named it a really bad name.

I had to change the
name to Tickle later. I asked six of my classmates
if they would join me.

They all said no. But the seventh one
finally said yes. So it took me a while to
get the sort of talent

to join me on one of
these crazy journeys. And then we raised money
from friends and family

and then promptly
ran out of money. And so I was raising money every
month just to keep it going.

I went off salary
myself for six months. And we were about to
go out of business. We were going to miss
payroll for the last six

people out of the 13 that
were still on payroll. We were about to miss
that on next Monday, and the money from the
venture firm for our series A

came in on that Friday
afternoon before the Monday we were going out of business. So we were inches from just
missing payroll and going away

with that first one.  One of the big lessons that I
learned from the whole thing

is if you're going
to do anything, you have to hit it hard. You have to raise
more than you think.

You have to talk to more
people about joining your company than you think. You have to talk
to more customers. You have to iterate faster.

You have to just make
decisions much, much quicker than you think. You've got to hit
everything very, very hard

in order to break through
in a startup environment. Those are some of
the early lessons that I didn't understand.

Even going to Princeton and
starting my own business, even going to Harvard
Business School and studying entrepreneurship
and having worked at a venture

capital firm, I still didn't
understand those things when I got out and was trying to
actually build my first venture.

So it was definitely a journey. HOST: That's really interesting. So it sounds like it was
a challenge initially,

and you had some hard lessons. But obviously, that led-- I guess just a quick follow-up. Do you think part of
that struggle, had it

gone more easily, do you
think that would have made you less successful down the road? Was there some of that hard
lessons valuable for you?

Were some of those hard lessons
valuable for you and just really sort of instilling? Someone can tell you you've got
to do those kinds of things.

But when you live it,
sometimes it's more motivating. JAMES CURRIER: That's
entirely right.

I think that the
suffering is part of it. You should not be
an entrepreneur if you don't like
suffering, if you

don't like changing your mind,
if you don't like being wrong. A lot of you are too
smart, and you've gotten

A's all the way through school. And then you got into
Stanford and you're just the king of the world,
the queen of the world.
You can do no wrong. Your parents think you're great. Running a venture capital--

running a startup is
the opposite of that. Your employees are
always mad at you. Your investors are always
disappointed with you.

The market doesn't really
want what you have. If they wanted what
you had last week, they don't want it this week.

Your competition comes in
and tells you you're crap. Suddenly, somebody
says something about you online that you're
actually cheating everyone.

You have to deal with
this all the time. You have to deal with the
negativity and the suffering all the time. And no one tells you that.

And in fact, when I went back
to my Harvard Business School fifth reunion, I stood up
in front of the whole class

when they asked us
what you've learned. I said, you guys
did a horrible job of preparing us for how much
suffering is involved with doing

one of these startups. And I was compelled to
do it, I had to do it, so I can't complain.

I didn't really have a choice in
my life based on my personality and who I was. But boy, you don't have any
cases about how this sucks

and about how much it hurts
and about how much you fear and how much you self-doubt
and all this stuff.

So that I think is something
you should realize. You only be a founder if
you can't not be a founder.

Only be a founder if you've
got this thing in your head that it will explode if you
don't make it into the world. Because otherwise,
you're not going

to be up for all the lessons
and all the challenge and the suffering. The other thing that I'll
say and then I'll shut up

is, we say at NFX there is
no corporate transformation without personal transformation.

So often the resistance and
the suffering that you get comes from your own
lack of willingness to change, to accept your
wrong, to adapt yourself.

Because none of us like to
be told that we're wrong, particularly when we've
gotten A's all of our careers and gotten the highest SAT
scores and all the things that

were required for you to
get into the university you're now in. So just be careful of that.

HOST: That's great. And I would love put a pin
in that and come back to it at the end, Ray
and Mike, to talk

about how I know intensity is a
big part of some of the courses you teach at Stanford. So I'd love to hear a little bit
how you're maybe incorporating

some of those hard lessons into
just the structure of the class. But Mike, I'd love to
turn to you now and hear a little bit more about your
background and your story,

your path into entrepreneurship,
and your path as a business leader and some of
the hard lessons that you learned along the way.

I'm going to yeah. MIKE LYONS: Yeah. Thanks, Pax. And I'll just
piggyback a little bit

on what James had to say
because I couldn't agree more about the suffering part.

And this is not well
taught in most programs

and entrepreneurship even
to this day, I must say. So where I started,
which was significantly

in time before James did his
first startup, when I did it,

there really was
no training much to speak at in universities
around this stuff.
We started all that stuff later.

It was an abrupt transition,
to say the least, for me. I was a heavy engineering guy
running a big group of control

systems engineers at Lockheed. And we were doing
extremely well.

So well, in fact,
that it was starting to interfere with my
PhD program at Stanford.

And at some point, I had to
make a choice which way to go. And I took the
entrepreneurship route

because the two things couldn't
live in the same room together. That was just too much work.

To James's point, the
intensity of building a business is there's no rest.

There's no break. There's no, oh, yeah, let's
take a couple of weeks off and relax and think about it.

So we were running that
kind of organization inside a large corporation.

And it got to the point where
it became clear the only way to do this was to spin it
out, which they helped us do.

And that was my
company number one. And we ended up eventually
taking that company public.

But to James's
earlier points, this is all nice to read about in
books and things like this.

But to actually do
it, it's brutal. It's what I would call,
as a martial artist,

I would call this a
full contact sport. And it can be rough mentally
and even physically,

and extremely demanding. And I think like Pax said
earlier, there are things--

and we'll talk about this
for the coursework later, but we can teach
a lot of process

around how to do this right,
how to think about it. But the grit part of it, when
it comes down to the day-to-day

pressures of being
an entrepreneur, and the feeling is you
cannot not succeed.

That's not going to work. And there's a lot of intensity
to doing this every minute.

And I think several
people have pointed out, entrepreneurs can go from
euphoria to total depression

in the space of less than a day,
depending upon what's going on

and what's happening, and
successes and failures. And you're constantly adjusting
and pivoting and moving.

And this is why when
we talk about building successful companies, one
of the most important things

is the team. Who are these folks? And ultimately, as an investor,
one of my fundamental questions

is always you guys
any good at this? OK?

Because the success of it
really depends on that. And you can have an
absolute A idea and a B team

and lose the whole thing. It's much better to have
an A team and a B idea

because then the A
team will figure out how to improve the B idea
and get it to work right.

Anyway, we can come
back to this many times. But most early stage ventures
require a significant number

of pivots early on
to get things dialed in so things start to work.
Pax?  HOST: Thanks, Mike.

First of all, I'm afraid we
lost half our audience already because we're starting
with how tough it is.

But that's great. And so I want to come back
to a lot of these ideas that both of you
are bringing up.

But I want to also
give Ray a chance here to talk a little bit
more about his background and his path to
entrepreneurship.

But just again, putting a pin
into this idea of intensity and how do you prepare for that.

And maybe you can't. Maybe some of these
lessons just have to be hard lessons that
you learn experientially.

But I also want to come back to
this idea of pivoting, which you hear a lot, or maybe
I hear it a lot

because I've sat in on
your classes many times. But this idea of being ready
to take an idea, iterate on it,

change it. I think, James, you
were saying you've got to be ready to make more
decisions more quickly than you would anticipate.

So thinking about how you
coach people through that or how you prepare
them for that.

Before we jump into
that, Ray, I would love to hear a little bit more
about your background as well.

You started similar to Mike. You were in academia, but you
were literally a professor in academia before moving
into the venture capital

space and the founder space. So I'd love to hear a little
bit more about your journey

and some of the hard lessons
you learned along the way. RAY LEVITT: And I
started my high school,
I decided I was an entrepreneur. And I wanted to do that.

And I launched a company
with a Swedish friend to import Swedish clogs
into South Africa.

It was a disaster. But we finally
eventually broke even

and decided we didn't want to be
in the import-export business. But anyway, I came
to Stanford to study
construction management. And this was in the early '70s.

And the business
school at that time was only talking to
public companies. They had no interest
in entrepreneurship.

I organized a course
for boards of directors for private companies, which got
me in trouble with the business

school because they
didn't like it. But my big mistake was I
stayed in school too long and became a PhD, and no one in
the industry would hire a PhD.

And I had never planned
to be a professor. So I don't ever give
career advice to students

because I say I
blundered into my career. I literally talked
to three or four

construction companies at the
time I graduated and they all said, PhD, you want
to be a professor? We can't use a PhD.

So I reluctantly became
a professor first at MIT for five years where there was
not very much entrepreneurship

other than one or two
companies in the Polaroid and digital equipment
and companies like that,

and moved back to Stanford
when there was a position, and then really got involved
with interesting graduate

students who wanted
to start companies. So the first company I launched
was an early application

of the AI at that time,
which was rule-based, chaining if-then rules
together to model

the knowledge of human experts. It was the opposite
of what we do today where we learn from data and
tell the experts what to do.

Here, we were interviewing
the experts and building models of their knowledge. And it was in medical diagnosis.

It was in construction safety. It was in a number of areas. But the first company I
launched was really a failure.

What happened was the
venture capitalist who had funded it lost
faith at the last minute

and left us floundering with
a payroll we couldn't meet. And unlike Mike and James, my
first project was a failure.

I had to tell the
friends and family who gave some of the early money
that they were wiped out from the recapitalization.

And I think what I
learned from that is that I was very lucky to
be in Silicon Valley, where

if you've had a failed startup,
you're not considered a loser. You're considered experienced.

And so it was easy to raise
money for the next company. That one was more successful.

We actually developed
a configuration system for data centers and
for oil refineries.

And the oil refinery one was
acquired by Bentley system. And the data center
configuration one

became a small public company. And I had met some
venture capitalists

when I ran that board of
directors conference early on, and I thought that's
something I'd really like to do later in my career.

After doing three startups and
becoming an angel investor, I took early retirement
from Stanford in 2017

and joined Blackhorn Ventures. So that's how I got into it. But I learned a
few other lessons

besides if you can't be
smart, be lucky, which my father had always told me. And if you have to
choose, be lucky.

But the same experience about
just the brutal hardship of going to friends and
family and telling them they

were wiped out, the
hardship of a VC changing their mind at the last
minute and leaving us stranded,

the hardship of pitching
to Sun Microsystems a solution which they'd
said they wanted.

But as we began
the presentation, the first question was
does it run on Solaris?

And we said no. And the guy said,
this meeting is over. And we were heartbroken
because this was going

to be our biggest customer. And so those kinds of
things where you just get

knocked down to the floor,
you dust yourself up. You hopefully have a
second in the corner who can wipe the blood off your face
and prop you up and send you

back into the ring
to fight again. So I agree with everything
that James and Mike said.

Another lesson that
I've seen several times early on is don't
start a company with a spouse, a sibling, a very
close friend with whom you've

never worked in business before,
because it's very hard when you disagree about
things later on to really resolve those issues.

And that slows down
your decision making. And so if you've had a
successful venture with someone like that, fine.

But if you haven't, I
would suggest avoiding it. But I'll guess we'll come
back to some of this later.

I'll hand it back to
Pax at this point. HOST: Wow. OK, not uplifting.

I mean, it's really
good to hear. All three of you have-- it sounds like for
all three of you--

so, first of all,
Ray, I didn't realize that you had also, it sounds
like in all three cases, you had the entrepreneurship
bug from a very early

on importing Swedish clogs. That's interesting. I don't think I heard
that story before.

But maybe, Ray, staying
a little bit longer then I want to come back to James and
Mike is from all three of you,

the founding moment is this
kind of moment of hardship, whether it's a hard
decision you had to make

or a failure and
hard consequence you had to communicate and take.

So, Ray, I guess
I would just say, as you're looking
at these companies-- I mean, how do
you identify that?

I mean, as you were
saying, in Silicon Valley, maybe that first failure that
someone has failed and is back

on the horse and
trying to ride again, that itself is some indication
of grit and persistence

that maybe is a valuable
trait of a founder. But how do you-- two questions I'm
going to ask around.

So the first, Ray, is
what are you looking for in identifying that trait? And two, because we
already got this question.

Someone said, hey, I'm
a founder right now. I'm going through that
suffering right now.

What are some of your
techniques or things that you recommend
to your students or to the people you're coaching
to get through that suffering?

So those are two questions. I apologize, Ray. So the first is if
you want to talk about what you're looking for
in identifying that persistence.

And two, how do you coach
people through that? RAY LEVITT: One
of the ways that I

try to do it is
give people really tough feedback during pitch
sessions and see how they react.

Do they get defensive and try
to defend their own position? Or are they open to
changing their idea?

That's maybe more about
flexibility than persistence. But there are a lot of field
of dreams type startup.

People in Silicon Valley is
full of engineers who think I've got a fabulous solution. Why can't these stupid
salespeople sell it?

I'll fire them and hire
some other salespeople that are better. And the new salespeople
can't sell it either.

And because they
live on commission, if they can't earn commission
in your company, they quit. And so the idea that maybe you
don't have product market fit,

can you accept that? And it's kind of
a personal failure because you thought
you were so brilliant.

And this is also
partly about failing. When people are
successful, they tend to attribute their success
to their intelligence

and their hard work and so on. When they fail,
they often end up reflecting about
why they failed.

And I think that's why Silicon
Valley and almost uniquely Silicon Valley will
invest in someone who's

had a failure because they
believe you've learned some lessons, and you won't
do the same harebrained thing

again, whether it's starting
to execute on a product that doesn't have product
market fit and firing

salespeople because they can't
sell it, instead of figuring out you've got the wrong solution.

By the way, those are things
I think you can teach, but experience is a much
better teacher than hearing it

from someone else. And I agree with what James
and Mike said about that. We can teach a lot
of the process.

But again, we look
for people that are open to being told
that it's a dumb idea or that for the following reason
it's going to fail because we've

seen this five times before. And if they keep on trying
to defend their solution instead of listening
and being open,

that's the main thing
I look for early on. During COVID, we invested
in a couple of companies

where we'd never
met the founders and we'd never gone
to dinner with a team and looked at some
of the chemistry

and the microexpression
and all the interactions

between the team. And those companies ended
up not being successful. And we saw companies
founded by good friends

where one of the
friends would quit his first time they came to a
decision they didn't agree with. And that was a real problem for
both those companies and so on.

HOST: Interesting. James, maybe throwing
it back to you just the same set of questions.

What are you looking for? How do you identify
that persistence?

How do you coach
or comfort people through that difficulty
when a founder is

up against that first
hard decision they have to communicate
or that first failure?

JAMES CURRIER: Yeah. I think that one of the
key things to identifying

persistence is how well
they are calibrated

toward how many ideas
they have to have in order to find one that works.

So if you grow up thinking
my dad had three ideas and one of them worked, so
you go through life thinking,

oh, if I have three good
ideas, one should work, as opposed to realizing you
need about 120 different ideas.

And so when one of your ideas
fails or one of your hires fails or one of your markets or
your customers fail or one

of your investors fail, if it
gets you too down because you think, wait a minute, it was
supposed to be one of three.

But if you think, hey,
it's one of 20, one of 120, then when it fails, you're
like, OK, that's fine.

I'll just come up
with a new one. And to Ray's point,
if you ask them even in a meeting, what about
this challenge you might face?

If they can drop it
and say, OK, I'll just come up with a new idea. I'll solve that problem again. You're right.

It is a problem. It is a barrier. If you can accept the
barrier because you know it's supposed to
take you 120 iterations,

if you calibrate to
120 not to three, then you're going to
be much more resilient.

It's like in Man's
Search for Meaning, the people who died in
the concentration camps

thought they were going
to be rescued next spring. But the people who
knew that it was going to take more iterations
and more months of waiting,

they're the ones who survived. And so I think that's
one thing we look for.

So flexibility
brings on resilience. And if you can, in
the first meetings,

notice that flexibility
and that comfort, that confidence to
accept yeah, you're right, Mr. VC, that is
going to be a problem.

Here are two ways I
think of mitigating it. They may or may not work,
but if they don't work, then I might try
this or this or this.

What do you think, Mr. VC? Do you think that would be
a good way to move through? That type of
confidence, that type

of thinking, that
usually underlies very flexible, resilient people. And so I was the CEO of four
venture backed companies.

All of them were successful. Not all of them were
billion dollar companies, but all the investors made
money in every company

because we were so resilient. We would just never die. And we would just stick around
long enough to get lucky when

the 120th idea, the 120th
iteration would actually work.

So that's what I'm looking for,
and that's how I coach them. I coach them through
the mindset of realizing

that it's OK that you're
on iteration number 94. Don't get discouraged.

That's what it takes. Like what you were told in
school before, what you thought before by watching The Social
Network movie that you just

have one idea and then it works,
you were wrong about that. That mindset was wrong.

Abandon that mindset. Adopt the true
mindset about reality. And then it's not as painful. And you can be more resilient.

And then you can get
lucky and be successful. HOST: That's really interesting
because that does seem to be--

when I think of resilience,
that almost just seems this kind of
personality trait that you either have
or you don't have.

But what you're
saying is there's a kind of a mindset and
maybe even a discipline of just you need to iterate.

You need to generate ideas. So if you only have one
idea, that's probably not enough for a startup.

You want to take
that idea and make sure you're expanding
on it, thinking of lots of other things, and
just brainstorming around

that could be a good first step. JAMES CURRIER: Yeah. A lot of founders are like,
well, how am I doing at this?
Did I get a higher valuation? Did my first idea work? Am I any good at this?

And that self-doubt creeps in. And so you have to avoid
that self-doubt just to realize that it's
mostly about failing.

And then I think what Churchill
says, continuing to fail but not losing enthusiasm
or something, that's

the critical thing. HOST: Continuing to fail
but not losing enthusiasm. I guess, Mike, I'm going to
hand it back over to you.

Is there anything
you would want to add to this kind of conversation? It sounds like if we're
talking about what it takes to launch a
successful venture,

the first thing is
that persistence, that willingness to fail, and
that willingness to try again.

So what are you looking for in
a team or a founder or a venture to indicate that that's there?

And two, again, how do you
coach people through it? How do you help them move
through those failures

and that challenge? MIKE LYONS: Yeah,
just a few add-ons.

What you're trying
to learn when you're becoming an effective
entrepreneur

is the feedback that comes from
the market, from the reality,

from the investors, all
the rest of that stuff. The entrepreneurs can't
take any of that personally.

It's not like we're attacking
you or something like that.

Entrepreneurs have
to learn, look, this is the reality of trying to
make these ventures successful.

And so all of this feedback
is in some various forms meaningful.

And they have to be able to
absorb it and figure out, OK,

is that important? And I need to do
something or not? I'm good where I am.

That's good. But they can't be
insulated from it or think it's some sort
of a personal attack.

And we see some of this
stuff in our course. And the course is designed
to give what I would say

is more operational feedback. In other words, you're trying
to learn operational skills

or experiential things
that in some ways simulate what it's like
to create a new venture,

and what are the things
that you run into when you're trying to do this.

And you personally
experience them. It's nice to read books and
all of this kind of stuff

to understand our case studies. But you don't really, I think,
completely understand it

until you experience that
pointed tough feedback where,

I think as James said,
you're at Stanford or you're at Harvard
